Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Modifying Electron-Electron Interactions to Control the Optical and Electronic Properties of Carbon Nanotubes
Award.AbstractNarration:
***TECHNICAL ABSTRACT***
Strong Coulomb interactions between charge carriers are a defining feature in low-dimensional electronic systems such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs). Phenomena associated with strong interactions often challenge theoretical descriptions and can lead to new breakthroughs in technology. In this project, electron-electron (e-e) interactions in CNTs will be varied by manipulating the dielectric environment surrounding the CNT. By studying individual CNT devices with e-e interactions "turned on" and then "turned off", the proposed experiments will test theories about bandgap renormalization, photoabsorption cross-section, photocurrent generation efficiency, impact ionization rates, and Luttinger liquid behavior. It is predicted that modifying the e-e interactions will causes dramatic changes in all these properties. Successful completion of the experiments will establish how electron interactions modify the properties of a nanomaterial, thereby generating fundamental knowledge about how to engineer nanomaterials with specific properties. The experiments will also directly contribute to the development of a solar cell design that breaks the conventional limit for solar energy conversion efficiency. The project supports PhD students and undergraduates who will be trained in a powerful combination of nanofabrication and nanometrology techniques. Nanoscience activities developed during the project will reach a broad audience, including rural highschool classrooms and introductory physics classes.

***NONTECHNICAL ABSTRACT***
Devices such as computer chips and photovoltaic cells are based on our understanding and control of electrons inside of materials. In most materials, electrons move independently of one another, which simplifies theory but limits the possibilities of discovering new phenomena. In materials such as carbon nanotubes, however, the repulsive interactions between electrons are extremely strong due to the nanoscale geometry of the material. If one electron dances about inside a carbon nanotube, the other electrons dance too. New phenomena related to this collective electron dance include faster signal propagation speeds and higher efficiency solar energy conversion. Much work is required to understand and utilize the phenomena related to the strong interactions between electrons in nanomaterials. In this project, measurements of individual carbon nanotubes will be made in a variety of conditions that are designed to promote or suppress the collective electron dance. Successful completion of the experiments will establish how electron interactions modify the properties of a nanomaterial, thereby generating fundamental knowledge about how to engineer nanomaterials with specific properties. The experiments will also directly contribute to the development of a solar cell design that breaks the conventional limit for solar energy conversion efficiency. The project supports PhD students and undergraduates who will be trained in a powerful combination of nanofabrication and nanometrology techniques. Nanoscience activities developed during the project will reach a broad audience, including rural high school classrooms and introductory physics classes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Devices such as computer chips and photovoltaic cells are based on our understanding and control of electrons inside of materials. In most materials, electrons move independently of one another, which simplifies theory but limits the possibilities of discovering new phenomena. In materials such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs), however, the repulsive interactions between electrons can be extremely strong because of the one-dimensional geometry of the system. Electronic devices made from CNTs offer unique opportunities to study and utilize new phenomena associated with strongly interacting electrons. However, experimental obstacles have limited progress in understanding interaction-driven phenomena in CNTs.

In this project, we overcame two key challenges to studying interaction-driven phenomena in CNTs. First, we worked with extremely clean CNTs. The pristine CNTs were clamped at either end, but otherwise suspended in empty space. This ensured that phenomena of interest were not obscured by the effects of an inhomogeneous environment. Second, we overcame the challenge of structural characterization. The atoms in a CNT can be bound together into various diameters and chiralities. There are approximately 500 possible structures, each of which absorbs light at a unique set of resonant wavelengths. Knowing the CNT structure is a crucial step in understanding its properties. We designed and built a novel microscope that focuses monochromatic light on an individual CNT while simultaneously recording the electrical currents caused by the light. By scanning a wide range of wavelengths, we can identify the exact CNT structure.

The key hypothesis of this project was that interactions between electrons cause significant changes to CNT properties. To test this hypothesis, we sought to modify the interaction strength. Interactions are mediated by the repulsive force between electric charges. To reduce these electric forces, we poured various dielectric liquids into the empty space surrounding the CNT. We found that changing the surrounding environment caused the CNT band gap to change by as much as 30%. This is the largest band gap renormalization effect observed in any material. The result has important implications for the design of CNTs transistors because optimization of the transistor properties must include careful choice of both CNT diameter and dielectric environment.

Our studies revealed unexpectedly large energy gaps in the metallic family of CNTs. Earlier researchers attributed such energy gaps to the short-range interactions between electrons on neighboring carbon atoms (the Mott-insulator model). Our work showed the importance of long-range interaction between electrons and provided experimental evidence for a competing model for the energy gaps in metallic CNTs (the excitonic-insulator model). We collaborated with theorists who are pioneering the excitonic-insulator model for strongly-correlated electrons in CNTs.

A potential technological application of strongly-interacting electrons is to improve the efficiency of photovoltaic solar cells. We explored this application by building tiny solar cell devices from individual CNTs. We compared the rate of light absorption to the electrical current generated. These measurements required new techniques to quantify light absorption by an individual CNT. We demonstrated our new techniques with unoptimized CNT devices and showed that 30% of the absorbed photons were converted into electrical current. After modifying the device design, we exceeded 70% yield for the conversion of photons to excited electrons. This is still less than commercially available silicon solar cells (up to 100% yield), however, theoretical predictions suggest that CNTs can exceed 200% yield which would enable new technological applications.

Three graduate students were trained in techniques for electronic and optical characterization of nanoscale systems. Additionally, three undergraduate students were supported by the project: two women and one African-American man. All three undergraduate students went onto PhD programs. A nanoscience workshop was given to 20 high school teachers who serve rural and low-income schools in Oregon. Every year the lab hosted two high-school girls for a week to build and measure their own nanoelectronic device as part of a campus-wide science camp. Our lab hosted physics demonstrations at a number of free-choice learning events, including OSU Discovery Days, Oregon Museum of Science and Industry Nano Days, and multiple Family Science Nights at local elementary schools.
